title: Silicon-Based One-dimensional Slow-Light Waveguide Modulator with High Modulation Efficiency for High-Speed Transmission
authors: Zhen Zhen, Xiaobin Liu, Siyue Jin, Lei Wang
abstract: We present a compact, reconfigurable slow-light silicon modulator fabricated using multi-project wafer technology. Operating at a group index of 22, our device achieves a low half-wave voltage-length product of 0.18 V•cm while maintaining a bandwidth of 30.5 GHz at a length of 200 μm. A specially designed serpentine electrode structure ensures phase matching between radio frequency and optical signals. The grating-based structure offers a wide tunable range of half-wave voltage-length product, reaching as low as 0.12 V•cm. The bandwidth ranges from 5 to 30 GHz in the S-band, providing flexibility for various applications that require different slow-light conditions. The device enables highly efficient optical modulation with significantly reduced power consumption, rendering it particularly suitable for high-density photonic integrated circuits and energy-efficient optical-interconnect applications.

title: Dual-Agent-based Resource Allocation for Synergistic Transmission of Classical and Quantum Signals in Multi-Core Fiber Networks
authors: Fengkai Sun, Yongmei Sun, Yaoxian Gao, Yuting Wang
abstract: To address the challenge of synergistic transmission for classical and quantum signals in multi-core fiber networks, this paper proposes a synergistic dual-agent reinforcement learning resource allocation scheme (S-DARL) based on multi-agent reinforcement learning framework. Two cooperating agents adopted in this scheme allocate the spectrum and core resources for quantum and classical signals, which are enabled to propagate together under the constraints of physical layer noise to achieve efficient encrypted data transmission. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed scheme significantly reduces the blocking probability and improves the overall network synergistic degree compared to previous state- of-the-art heuristic methods.

title: Enhancing Security in Rayleigh Fading Channel with Best Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface
authors: Md. Fahmid Ibne Afzal, Md. Zahurul Islam Sarkar, Abid Hasan
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Information and Communication Technology (EICT)
abstract: This paper investigates the enhancement of security in Rayleigh fading channels using the best reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS). The study focuses on a scenario involving a single legitimate receiver and a single eavesdropper, both operating over a Rayleigh fading channel. The impact of key parameters such as the eavesdroppers average signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), the number of reflecting elements of a RIS, and the number of RIS is thoroughly examined. Analytical expressions for the ergodic secrecy capacity (ESC) are derived to evaluate the systems secrecy performance. Furthermore, a comparative analysis is carried out between systems with and without RIS integration. The results confirm that deploying RIS significantly improves the ergodic secrecy capacity in wireless systems, thereby providing a foundation for further research and potential realworld implementations.

title: Gaussian Pulse-Based PSS-PPM Scheme for Optical Integrated Sensing and Communication Systems
authors: Fengyuan Tian, Jian Zhao, Yunfan Zhang, Gan Zheng, Tianhua Xu
abstract: This paper presents a Gaussian pulse-based optical Integrated Sensing and Communication (ISAC) system using the Pulse Sequence Sensing and Pulse Position Modulation (PSS-PPM) scheme. In this system, a binary input stream is mapped into time slots, with each slot modulating a pseudo-noise (PN) sequence via PPM. The Gaussian pulse is employed due to its compact time-frequency localization and low sidelobe energy, which are advantageous for both communication and sensing tasks. Communication reliability is quantified using the bit error rate (BER), while sensing accuracy is assessed via the root mean square error (RMSE) of distance estimation, derived from round-trip delay using cross-correlation and quadratic fitting. Performance is evaluated in both single-user and two-user scenarios under atmospheric turbulence modeled by the Rytov approximation. The results demonstrate that the proposed sys-tem achieves reliable communication and high-precision sensing, validating the effectiveness of Gaussian pulse shaping in optical ISAC applications.

title: Error-based ADRC augmented with a residual compensator for control performance improvement with application to an aerodynamic plant
authors: Maciej Marcin Michałek, Karol Dębski
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Numerous practical applications have revealed significance efficiency and high robustness of the Active Disturbance Rejection Control (ADRC) scheme in the problem of tracking control of highly uncertain and perturbed dynamical systems. The error-based ADRC (eADRC) allows additionally reducing the information content about a reference trajectory, where the availability of the reference signal’s time derivatives is not required. The main limitation, however, of the conventional ADRC (also in the error form) applied with a linear extended state observer (LESO) comes from a need of a wide enough observer’s bandwidth, which leads to large observer gains, and in the case of a noisy feedback can lead to a control performance degradation and to an excessive amplification of high parasitic frequencies in a control signal. In this paper we propose to mitigate the above mentioned limitation by augmenting the eADRC with an add-on mechanism called the residual compensation which enables reducing a bandwidth of LESO while keeping (or even improving) the resultant tracking control performance in both a tracking accuracy and a control cost. A presentation of the residual compensation idea for the error-based ADRC is followed by its experimental verification using a highly uncertain laboratory-scale aerodynamic plant.

title: Multi-UAV Mission Planning with No-Fly Zones Using Genetic Algorithm
authors: Kejun Dong, Xiaoxiang Hu, Haichao Zhang
publish: 2025 9th International Workshop on Control Engineering and Advanced Algorithms (IWCEAA)
abstract: This paper decomposes the multi-UAV mission planning problem into two parts: mission allocation and trajectory planning. By formulating the multi-UAV mission allocation problem as a Multiple Traveling Salesman Problem (MTSP), the objective is to minimize the total time required for UAVs to complete their missions. First, mission planning is performed without considering no-fly zones, using a genetic algorithm for mission allocation. The algorithm employs a two-segment chromosome encoding method, and through operations such as selection, crossover, and mutation, a reasonable mission distribution is achieved. Next, mission planning is carried out with the inclusion of no-fly zones. Based on the previous mission allocation, the initial paths are modified due to the presence of no-fly zones. The paths requiring modification are selected, a weighted directed graph is constructed, and Dijkstra algorithm is applied for trajectory planning, ensuring the avoidance of no-fly zones. This adjustment significantly reduces the mission planning time and improves the overall efficiency. Finally, the proposed approach is validated under both scenarios: with and without no-fly zones.

title: Investigation of Weakly-coupled Multi-core EDFAs With Core and Cladding Pump Schemes
authors: Yuanpeng Ding, Baolong Zhu, Lei Shen, Juniie Qi, Xin Huang, Zhaolong Liao, Shiqi Zhou, Lei Zhang, Jie Luo
abstract: We constructed core-pumped and claddingpumped 4-core EDF amplifiers. With multi-wavelength channel signals, both exhibited gain around 25 dB, while the core-pumped demonstrated a maximum CGD of 1.299 dB and NF below 6 dB.

title: Biogas Power Plant Operation Modeling based on Statistical and Grey-box Methods
authors: Petra A. Reisz, Thomas I. Strasser
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Biogas plants have been the subject of modeling and research in recent years. Such a plant is a system consisting of several components, the most important of which are the combined heat and power (CHP) unit that produces electricity and heat, the organic feed receiving area, the digester and the gas storage. All of these components have separate and detailed models developed for different purposes. A missing system approach that provides a sufficient level of detail and correlation between feeding, biogas production rate, storage level and CHP output was identified. Therefore, this work presents the concept of an approach that uses a deeper system understanding combined with processing of big amount of data rather than the popular fully machine learning based models. It outlines the methodology for establishing a relationship between CHP power and gas storage level in both forward and backward coupling. Possible physics based models are presented, which should serve as a predictor between the storage level of the biogas power plant and the feedstock. Finally, the individual steps are linked to a system-level approach that captures the fact that the power generated affects the state of the system and vice versa. The models presented are under development and use a sophisticated mix of statistical, data-driven and physical modelling methods. As input, they require recorded data that is minimally in detail and generally available for all biogas power plants. Together with the presented approach, the developed model should be able to serve as a digital twin of an arbitrary power plant that can be integrated into energy system models. Additionally, it should deliver quality indicators for the biogas produced at the respective plant. As such, the proposed methodology offers added value over existing approaches, which are often unidirectional or focused solely on individual components.

title: Kaarigar: Region-Specific Motif Generation Using Stable Diffusion for Customizable Textile Design
authors: Nitya Shukla, Varun Tiwari, Amit Kumar Bairwa
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Computing Technologies (ICACT)
abstract: India boasts one of the most splendid textile histories in the world, with each region imbued with its unique motifs, methods, and cultural meanings. However, due to rapid industrialization, the obsolescence of artisan practices, and limited digital viability, visibility and legacy of these traditional designs has diminished. In response to these challenges, an AI driven system is designed to digitize and fabricate regionally unique Indian textile patterns. Using Stable Diffusion to develop the motifs, BLIP to describe the images, and Gemini to contextualize the culture, the AI system produces a complete visual and textual form that is anchored into heritage. A user can access an authentic design mock with historical significance by entering a name of the region of interest. This AI system provides designers and product manufacturers the ability to design culturally aware objects, while keeping traditional art practices alive. By creating an intelligent generative AI approach that embodies cultural intelligence we advocate for heritage preservation, mass customization, and creative innovation on a shared platform at scale.

title: Filter Bank Multicarrier Systems with Index Modulation
authors: Pallavi Khairkar, Anuradha Sundru
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: In Filter Bank Multicarrier with Index Modulation (FBMC-IM) is aninnovative multicarrier transmission technique designed to manage the shortcomings of traditional Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing(OFDM). By leveraging filter banks and index modulation, FBMC-IM achieves superior spectral efficiency and significantly reduces out-of-ban emissions, making it a promising candidate regarding the upcoming wireless communication systems. This paper conducts a comprehensive performance analysis of FBMC-IM under diverse wireless channel conditions, including Additive White Gaussian Noise (AWGN), Rayleigh, Rician and Nakagami-m fading channels. Through extensive MATLAB-based simulations, we estimate the Bit Error Rate (BER) to assess the framework’s resilience to multipath fading and other channel impairments. The results demonstrate that FBMC-IM delivers outstanding performance in AWGN channels, reflecting its robustness in idealized conditions. In contrast, its performance under fading channels varies, with the Nakagami-m fading model showing notable flexibility due to its adjustable fading parameter, which enables better adaptation to varying channel conditions. These insights underscore the potential of FBMC-IM to strengthen the reliability and productivity of future wireless systems, particularly in complex and unpredictable environments, paving the way for its adoption in 5 G and beyond. In addition to BER evaluation, this study also highlights the quantitative spectral efficiency gains of FBMC-IM over OFDM, filter bank design trade-offs, and the role of index modulation schemes.

title: Comprehensive Analysis of Lung Cancer Detection using Deep Learning Approaches
authors: N. V. Ramya Devi Kotla, Suresh Babu Mudunuri
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: Lung cancer is one of the leading cause of cancerrelated deaths all over the world because of its high mortality rate and complexities involved in diagnosis. This study demonstrates a survey for existing Deep Learning (DL)-based approaches for lung cancer detection, which focuses on their techniques and performances. The DL approaches are categorized into three types, namely DL-based approaches, hybrid approaches, and transformer-based approaches. Each category is analyzed based on the model’s architecture, feature extraction strategies, and detection accuracy. The existing models achieve high precision but suffer from high complexity, overfitting, and limited generalization, and transformer-based models increase computation. This study identifies the challenges such as data imbalance, variability, and interpretability for clinical settings. The performance of the model is evaluated based on performance metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-Score. These findings give insights for developing a more generalizable, lightweight, and robust models for effective lung cancer detection.

title: Decentralized Real-Time Planning for Multi-UAV Cooperative Manipulation via Imitation Learning
authors: Shantnav Agarwal, Javier Alonso-Mora, Sihao Sun
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Multi-Robot and Multi-Agent Systems (MRS)
abstract: Existing approaches for transporting and manipulating cable-suspended loads using multiple UAVs along reference trajectories typically rely on either centralized control architectures or reliable inter-agent communication. In this work, we propose a novel machine learning-based method for decentralized kinodynamic planning that operates effectively under partial observability and without inter-agent communication. Our method leverages imitation learning to train a decentralized student policy for each UAV by imitating a centralized kinodynamic motion planner with access to privileged global observations. The student policy generates smooth trajectories using physics-informed neural networks that respect the derivative relationships in motion. During training, the student policies utilize the full trajectory generated by the teacher policy, leading to improved sample efficiency. Moreover, each student policy can be trained in under two hours on a standard laptop. We validate our method in both simulation and real-world environments to follow an agile reference trajectory, demonstrating performance comparable to that of centralized approaches.

title: Spectrum-Efficient RoF Link Using MRR-Based Phase Shifters for Signal Demultiplexing
authors: Chenhui Liu, Wenjie Xuan, Xiaoyang Che, Yu Liu, Junyi Zhang, Ruiqi Zheng, Long Huang, Jiejun Zhang, Jianping Yao
abstract: We propose and demonstrate a novel spectrum-efficient radio-over-fiber (RoF) link using a dual-drive Mach-Zehnder modulator (DD-MZM) to multiplex two radio-frequency (RF) signals with an identical RF carrier frequency at the transmitter and two microring resonators (MRRs) to demultiplex the two RF signals at a receiver. The proposed RoF link offers a two-fold increase in transmission capacity with a simple configuration and compensate chromatic dispersion at the same time.

title: Study on Field Emission Characteristics of CuCr25 with Different Cr Grain Sizes
authors: Jun Xiao, Jie Zhang, Junxiang Liu, Lu Zhu, Qingdan Huang, Le Luan, Xiaoguang Zhou
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Energy Engineering and Power Systems (EEPS)
abstract: The bright and dense plasma near the cathode, together with the ablation crater formed on the cathode surface, is collectively defined as a cathode spot. The formation of a new spot involves a complex physical process. Research on the generation and emission characteristics of cathode spots provides theoretical support for the regulatory mechanism of arc initial diffusion from the perspective of its formation source. CuCr alloy is commonly used as the contact material in vacuum interrupters. As vacuum interrupters develop toward higher voltage levels, the primary challenge to overcome is how to improve the insulation withstand voltage performance of the contact gap. However, the breakdown characteristics of the contact gap remain unclear. The needle-plate electrode breakdown experiments of CuCr 25 prepared by two different processes were carried out, and the experimental results showed that the cathode spots of CuCr25-A were more likely to split and the ablation morphology was shallow. The smaller the Cr phase size, the more the number of cathode spots, the lighter the ablation.

title: Twisted and Folded: Increasing the Capacity of Clos-WSS Optical Cross-Connect (OXC)
authors: Jiemin Lin, Gangxiang Shen, Yongcheng Li
abstract: In a conventional Clos-WSS optical cross-connect (OXC) constructed using N×N wavelength-selective switches (WSSs), a portion of WSS ports must remain idle to satisfy the strictly non-blocking (SNB) condition, leading to inefficient utilization of network ports. In this paper, we propose the TF-Clos-WSS OXC, which integrates the twisted and folded Clos (TF-Clos) architecture into the conventional Clos-WSS OXC. Numerical results show that the TF-Clos-WSS OXC significantly improves capacity compared to the conventional Clos-WSS OXC. Furthermore, the analysis reveals that the wavelength dimension has a more significant impact on the capacity of the Clos-WSS OXC than on the TF-Clos-WSS OXC.

title: Exploring the Potential of 5G Wireless for Healthcare, Automotive, and Industrial Automation in Real-Time
authors: V. Samuthira Pandi, D. Anbarasu, E. Sivajothi, Ala H. Jaber, Sravanthi, G. Karthikeyan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Computing Technologies (ICACT)
abstract: 5G wireless technology has ushered in a new era of connectivity, characterized by ultra-low latency, high-speed data transfer, and massive device interconnectivity. By providing the foundation for real-time data exchange and intelligent decision making, these developments could transform sectors such as healthcare, automotive, and industrial automation. In healthcare, it enables applications like telemedicine, remote surgery, and instant patient monitoring, allowing medical devices and professionals to communicate seamlessly. 5G Solution in Automotive Sector: 5G forms the basic framework and enablement of connected and autonomous vehicles in Automotive Sector via reliable vehicle-to-everything (V2X) communication for safer roads and a better traffic flow. Meanwhile, 5G enhances industrial automation through ultra-reliable low-latency communication (URLLC), improving robotic process automation, predictive maintenance, and smart factory processes. However, the deployment of 5G across these sectors also comes with hurdles such as infrastructure costs, security vulnerabilities, and regulatory constraints. The extension of 5G capability relies on the deployment of small-cell networks and edge computing architectures to guarantee real-time responsiveness and high reliability. Additionally, given the need for cybersecurity and data privacy, secure encryptions and AI-based threat detections are crucial to safeguard sensitive data flowing through 5G networks. 4. Cybersecurity and Safety Navigating these issues will demand multidisciplinary cooperation among technology creators, regulatory agencies, and sector participants to create common protocols and interoperability models that allow for seamless integration. Innovations in artificial intelligence, cloud and the IoT will determine the future of 5G solutions in automotive, health care, and industrial automation. In combination with 5G, these technologies will enable next-level innovations to emerge, including AI-powered diagnostics, autonomous driving, and fully automated industrial ecosystems. These trends will not only improve efficiency and safety shall be unprecedented for their respective impact, but will also pave the way for innovative business models and services that simply wouldn't be possible without 5G as a prerequisite.

title: Incentive Mechanism Design for Photovoltaic Generation Under Dual Information Asymmetry and Fairness Preference
authors: Wencheng Chen, Jun Wang, Jeng-Shyang Pan, Jin Wang
publish: 2025 5th IEEE International Conference on Energy Engineering and Power Systems (EEPS)
abstract: Driven by carbon neutrality and energy transition goals, photovoltaic (PV) generation has become a key component of China's power system, yet incentive inefficiency caused by information asymmetry and behavioral imbalance remains a policy challenge. This paper develops a non-cooperative principalagent model between grid companies and PV enterprises that incorporates dual information asymmetry and fairness preferences. Under complete rationality, disadvantageous inequity, and advantageous inequity, the optimal contracts and effort levels are derived. Results show that fairness preferences significantly reshape the incentive structure: under disadvantageous inequity, the grid company should raise quantity-based and reduce fixed subsidies to strengthen motivation, while the opposite applies under advantageous inequity. Fairness preferences also affect enterprise effort and generation output, moderated by market composition. The findings provide theoretical and policy guidance for designing differentiated and dynamic PV subsidy mechanisms to enhance renewable energy efficiency.

title: Design of a pump coupling mode multiplexer based on multi-plane light conversion
authors: Xiaoyu Yan, Zhifeng Wang, Liang Zhang, Heming Wei, Mengshi Zhu, Fufei Pang
abstract: Multi-plane light conversion (MPLC) combines free-space propagation with spatial phase modulation to enable efficient and complex spatial light transformation. Addressing the challenge of precise multi-wavelength, multi-mode field generation and coupling in specialty fibers, this paper presents an end-to-end design and optimization of an MPLC system using a wavefront matching algorithm. The system converts an input array—one 980 nm pump beam and three 1550 nm signal beams—into the LP<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">01</inf>, LP<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">11a</inf>, LP<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">11b</inf>, and LP<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">21</inf> modes supported by a ring-core fiber (RCF). By inversely designing a series of phase plates, a compact device integrating pump coupling and mode multiplexing is realized. Systematic analysis of phase plate number and spacing reveals an optimal setup of four plates spaced 20 mm apart, yielding insertion loss (IL) below 0.5 dB, mode-dependent loss (MDL) of 0.8 dB, and average mode purity (MP) above 94%. These results validate the MPLC device as an efficient, high-fidelity solution for generating structured composite fields in advanced mode-division multiplexing fiber systems, such as ring-core fiber amplifiers.

title: Performance Analysis of UAV-Assisted Dual-Hop Optical Wireless Communication System with Spatial Diversity
authors: Pu Li, Zaichen Zhang
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: In this paper, we analyzes the performance of a UAV-assisted dual-hop OWC system with spatial diversity. We investigate the impact of factors such as path loss, atmospheric turbulence, non-zero boresight pointing errors, and angle of arrival fluctuations on the system performance. The gammagamma distribution is chosen as the atmospheric turbulence model, and closed-form expressions for parameters such as channel fading coefficient probability density function (PDF), outage probability and bit error rate (BER) are derived. Based on the derived closed-form expressions, numerical simulations are carried out to determine the effects of factors such as beamwidth, UAV position, and diversity schemes on system performance. The results show that tunable parameters, such as UAV position and beamwidths have a significant impact on system performance. Moreover, to achieve the optimal system performance, the length of the relay-to-destination link should be shorter than the source-to-relay, and the use of spatial diversity in the relay-to-destination link can enhance system performance more effectively.

title: PEACE: Towards Efficient Project-Level Efficiency Optimization via Hybrid Code Editing
authors: Xiaoxue Ren, Jun Wan, Yun Peng, Zhongxin Liu, Ming Liang, Dajun Chen, Wei Jiang, Yong Li
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated significant capability in code generation, but their potential in code efficiency optimization remains underexplored. Previous LLM-based code efficiency optimization approaches exclusively focus on function-level optimization and overlook interaction between functions, failing to generalize to real-world development scenarios. Code editing techniques show great potential for conducting project-level optimization, yet they face challenges associated with invalid edits and suboptimal internal functions. To address these gaps, we propose PEACE, a novel hybrid framework for Project-Level code Efficiency optimization through Automatic Code Editing, which also ensures the overall correctness and integrity of the project. PEACE integrates three key phases: dependency-aware optimizing function sequence construction, valid associated edits identification, and efficiency optimization editing iteration. To rigorously evaluate the effectiveness of PEACE, we construct PEACEXEC, the first benchmark comprising 146 real-world optimization tasks from 47 high-impact GitHub Python projects, along with highly qualified test cases and executable environments. Extensive experiments demonstrate PEACE’s superiority over the state-of-the-art baselines, achieving a 69.2% correctness rate (pass@1), +46.9% opt rate, and 0.840 speedup in execution efficiency. Notably, our PEACE outperforms all baselines by significant margins, particularly in complex optimization tasks with multiple functions. Moreover, extensive experiments are also conducted to validate the contributions of each component in PEACE, as well as the rationale and effectiveness of our hybrid framework design.

title: Optimizing Communication Technology Selection for Advanced Metering Infrastructure (AMI) Based on Regional Characteristics Using AHP
authors: Ignatius Rendroyoko, Sugeng Hidayat, Sudarmono Sasmono, Dhanu Rediansyah, Satrio Rizq Mauladito, Nanang Hariyanto
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on High Voltage Engineering and Power Systems (ICHVEPS)
abstract: The successful deployment of Advanced Metering Infrastructure (AMI) is highly dependent on the selection of the right communication technology, which should be tailored to the geographical and operational characteristics of the target area. This study presents a structured decision-making framework to optimize communication technology selection for AMI by applying the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP). The analysis incorporates both technical and non-technical evaluation criteria, including communication performance metrics (e.g., bandwidth, data rate, latency, coverage, and reliability) and cost-related aspects (e.g., installation, operational, and maintenance costs), in addition to data security considerations. The assessment focused on three different regional classifications - urban-commercial, rural, and industrial - each with unique infrastructure readiness and AMI functionality requirements. Expert judgment was used to assign relative weights to each criterion through pairwise comparisons using Expert Choice software. The resulting priority weights were applied to evaluate various communication technology alternatives, such as Wi-Fi, NB-IoT, LoRa, RF Mesh, PLC, and cellular technologies. The findings revealed that Wi-Fi is best suited for urban commercial areas, NB-IoT for rural areas, and cellular networks for industrial zones. These results provide strategic insights for service providers and policy makers to ensure efficient, reliable, and context-appropriate deployment of AMI communications across different geographical locations.

title: IncrFuzz: LLM-Driven Incremental Fuzz Driver Generation for Library APIs
authors: Xiao Feng, Taotao Gu, Shuaibing Lu, Xiaohui Kuang
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th International Conference on Data Science in Cyberspace (DSC)
abstract: Library fuzzing requires a fuzz driver (or harness) to convert fuzzer-generated bytes into valid API calls with correct ordering and resource handling. However, writing such drivers is time-consuming, error-prone, and difficult to scale, often becoming a bottleneck in applying fuzzing to new libraries. This paper presents IncrFuzz, an incremental driver-generation framework that couples multi-dimensional function prioritization with large language model (LLM)-based iterative repair. The framework begins by ranking functions with a composite score derived from coverage data and code attributes to pinpoint high-value targets. It then enriches LLM prompts with project-specific test context to synthesize semantically correct libFuzzer drivers, and employs a compile-feedback “generate-validate-repair” loop to improve buildability. Experiments on 6 OSS-Fuzz libraries demonstrate that IncrFuzz elevates the average compilation success rate to 65.75%, produces 1.4 to over <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$25 \times$</tex> more newly covered lines than a random baseline, and uncovers 623 and 2,140 additional lines in cJSON and libpcap, respectively. These results indicate that IncrFuzz can significantly extend existing driver coverage without manual effort, providing a practical path toward LLM-enabled large-scale library fuzzing.

title: Distance-Aware DRL-Based Routing Strategies in QKD-ONs
authors: Shailendra Raghuwanshi, Suman Palrecha, Vimal Bhatia, Xue Hu, Bowen Chen
abstract: Resource constraints in quantum key distribution-secured optical networks (QKD-ONs) frequently prevent successful quantum light-path request (QLR) fulfillment. This work introduces a routing and resource assignment (RRA) strategy prioritizing minimal transmission distance to address this limitation. The proposed scheme employs a metric evaluating fiber length to determine optimal quantum signal paths. By minimizing cumulative (photon) travel distance, the proposed approach improves resource efficiency. The proposed distance-aware deep reinforcement learning (DA-DRL) based scheme’s performance is evaluated against first-fit (FF) and random-fit (RF) methods, across two network topologies NSFNET and UBN24. Simulation results show that, for NSFNET, the proposed approach scheme reduces blocking by 6.18% and 9.18% and for UBN24, by 2.71% and 3.41%, when compared to FF and RF respectively.

title: Non-Invasive Blood Pressure and Heart Rate Estimation Using Remote Photoplethysmography and Machine Learning Models
authors: Minal Yadavrao Barhate, Aum Santosh Mishra, Vedant Narayan Mehar, Piyush Jwalaprasad Mishra, Krish Mukund Mhashakhetri, Krish Kiran More, Saniya Sanjay Meshram
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: Continuous non-invasive monitoring of cardiovascular parameters such as blood pressure (BP) and heart rate (HR) is critical for early diagnosis and monitoring health. In this study, we describe a camera-based approach to extract contactless BP and HR using remote photoplethysmography (rPPG) data and machine learning. First, we developed a multi-stage rPPG pipeline that can extract PPG signals from facial videos with POS and CHROM-based algorithms, including adaptive region-of-interest fusion, wavelet denoising, motion artifact reduction, and normalization. The resulting signals were validated against a contact-based PPG device and achieved a highly significant correlation ($r=0.86$), and evaluated by signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), HR error, and mean squared error (MSE). In a second, supervised ML step, contrasting supervised ML models - Random Forest and XGBoost - were trained on real dataset, achieving $\mathbf{R}^{2}=0.90$ (SBP), $\mathbf{R}^{2}=0.92$ (DBP), and $\mathbf{R}^{2}=0.99$ (HR). These results demonstrate the feasibility of real-time, non-contact cardiovascular monitoring that could serve as a telehealth or remote healthcare application.

title: Perceptual Data Visualization for Remote Assistance of Automated Vehicles: A Design Study for Perception Modification
authors: Tobias Kerbl, Tarik Isildar, Yassine El Alami, Frank Diermeyer
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Teleoperation is emerging as a crucial fallback for automated vehicles when facing unforeseen edge cases that exceed their capabilities. This work focuses on the remote assistance concept Perception Modification, where a remote operator resolves perception-related issues (e.g., neglecting false-positive detections) by modifying the vehicle’s environmental model without assuming full control. Effective perceptual data visualization is essential, enabling the remote operator to achieve sufficient situational awareness to identify perception-related issues while maintaining an acceptable mental workload. However, for Perception Modification it remains unclear which perceptual data should be visualized and how. This research implements and evaluates three visualization approaches tailored to Perception Modification. The conducted online user study shows a preference for integrating perceptual data into a single view, though further development is needed for real-world deployment.

title: Follicle Fusion: Integrating External and Internal Factors for Smart Hair Product Recommendations
authors: Ms. Sharmikha Sree R, S Meera, Kaviyaselvi V, S Divya Darsshini, Sreenithi R
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Computing Technologies (ICACT)
abstract: Hair and scalp health are vital components of overall well-being, yet they are often neglected and influenced by a range of internal and external factors. In this study, we present an advanced machine learningbased system designed to predict scalp and hair conditions while offering personalized recommendations. By leveraging Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) for scalp image analysis and BERT for processing text-based data, our approach integrates diverse inputs, including real-time user information, stress levels, and environmental factors such as local climate and water quality. This multimodal framework enables a comprehensive understanding of how these elements influence hair health, supporting the development of highly individualized care strategies. Key contributions of this research include the novel combination of image and text analysis, real-time environmental data integration, and a scalable solution for tailored haircare. Follicle Fusion aims to empower users with valuable, data-driven insights, helping them take control of their hair health with precision and informed decision-making.

title: RaDL: Relation-aware Disentangled Learning for Multi-Instance Text-to-Image Generation
authors: Geon Park, Seon Bin Kim, Gunho Jung, Seong-Whan Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: With recent advancements in text-to-image (T2I) models, effectively generating multiple instances within a single image prompt has become a crucial challenge. Existing methods, while successful in generating positions of individual instances, often struggle to account for relationship discrepancy and multiple attributes leakage. To address these limitations, this paper proposes the relation-aware disentangled learning (RaDL) framework. RaDL enhances instance-specific attributes through learnable parameters and generates relation-aware image features via Relation Attention, utilizing action verbs extracted from the global prompt. Through extensive evaluations on benchmarks such as COCO-Position, COCO-MIG, and DrawBench, we demonstrate that RaDL outperforms existing methods, showing significant improvements in positional accuracy, multiple attributes consideration, and the relationships between instances. Our results present RaDL as the solution for generating images that consider both the relationships and multiple attributes of each instance within the multi-instance image.

title: How Can Infrastructure as Code Accelerate Data Center Bring-ups? A Case Study at ByteDance
authors: Xianhao Jin, Yifei Feng, Yufei Gao, Yongning Hu, Jie Huang, Kun Xia, Luchuan Guo
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Software companies are establishing new data centers to enhance software performance with lower response times as well as meet security requirements for storing local user data. ByteDance also has a strong need to deploy its services to new data centers worldwide quickly and with minimal error. Unfortunately, this process can also be time-consuming and error-prone, e.g., services often have dependencies on one another, requiring a strict deployment execution order. Moreover, the high similarity between resources in the new and the old data centers enables minimal modifications and maximizes the reuse of existing infrastructure configurations while providing the ability of global resource management. Additionally, manual migration across data centers often requires multiple confirmation check-points, which can significantly slow down the process. Therefore, to accelerate the new data center bring-ups, we adopt the idea of Infrastructure as code (IaC) which is a practice to automatically configure system dependencies and to provision local and remote instances [41]. In this work, we propose ByteRollout, an automatic intent-based software resource deployment system that is able to take customized infrastructure configurations as input and actuate deployments accordingly. We also assess ByteRollout in the following events of new data centers creations driven by site reliability engineering (SRE) teams. The evaluation results demonstrate that ByteRollout significantly accelerates the data center bring-up process, saving months of human effort and reducing costs by millions of USD simultaneously. The results also highlight that the Infrastructure as Code practice can be leveraged in the context of data center setups, offering benefits such as reduced process time and minimized errors throughout the deployment.

title: Research on Big Data Mining and Anomaly Detection Model in Network Traffic Analysis
authors: Qingwei Meng, Jiquan Wen
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th International Conference on Power, Intelligent Computing and Systems (ICPICS)
abstract: This study aims to solve the problem of the difficulty in accurately identifying abnormal behaviors in network traffic analysis, and proposes an anomaly detection model that combines big data mining and least squares optimization. The study first extracts feature from network traffic data, and improves data processing efficiency and model accuracy through data preprocessing, feature selection and dimension reduction. At the same time, a network abnormal traffic monitoring system is proposed. The system architecture includes a data acquisition module, a feature extraction module, an anomaly detection module, and a result analysis module. The simulation results show that when the data set size reaches millions of records, the anomaly detection accuracy of the model reaches 98.6%, and the false alarm rate is less than 1.2%. In complex network environments, especially in the case of high concurrent traffic and high changes, the model still maintains a high detection accuracy. The robustness and applicability of the model are further verified by adjusting parameter comparison. This study provides an efficient and scalable solution for anomaly detection in network traffic, which is of great significance in dealing with increasingly complex network security threats.

title: Automated Prompt Generation for Code Intelligence: An Empirical study and Experience in WeChat
authors: Kexing Ji, Shiyun Fu, Cuiyun Gao, Yujia Chen, Zezhou Yang, Chaozheng Wang, Yuetang Deng
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Large Code Models (LCMs) have demonstrated potential in advancing various code intelligence tasks. However, their effectiveness can be greatly influenced by the quality of the prompts. Current prompt design strategies in code intelligence studies are mostly manually generated, which could be time-consuming and extremely rely on the base LCMs and tasks. Although automated prompt generation (APG) has been investigated in the natural language processing field, it has not attracted sufficient attention and been well explored in the code intelligence tasks. Considering the various tasks and black-box nature of LCMs faced by developers in practice, it is essential to automate the prompt generation process.To mitigate the gap, we empirically investigate the two important parts in APG, including Instruction Generation (IG) and Muti-Step Reasoning (MSR). The instruction generation part aims at providing a task-related description for instructing LCMs to effectively accomplish specific tasks; while the multistep reasoning part aims at guiding LCMs to produce a series of logical steps before arriving at the final answer. For each part, we evaluate the widely-used APG methods on four open-source LCMs and three code intelligence tasks, i.e., code translation (PL-PL), code summarization (PL-NL) and API recommendation (NL-PL). Experimental results indicate that the two parts in APG can dramatically enhance the performance of the code intelligence tasks compared with the basic prompts. Based on the results, we further propose a novel APG approach by combining the best methods of the two studied parts of APG. Experiments show that the proposed APG approach achieves an average improvement of 28.38% with respect to CodeBLEU for the code translation, 58.11% in terms of ROUGE-L for the code summarization and 84.53% in SuccessRate@1 for the API recommendation over the basic prompts, respectively. To validate the effectiveness in industrial scenario, we further evaluate our approach on WeChat-Bench, a proprietary dataset from the WeChat Group in Tencent for API recommendation, achieving an average improvement of 148.89% in MRR.

title: Quantum Public Key Encryption Protocol Based on Decoy States and Hash Function
authors: Zedong Li, Jingtao Wang, Xinyu Chen
publish: 2025 2nd International Symposium on AI and Cybersecurity (ISAICS)
abstract: Quantum key distribution provides an effective means for achieving information-theoretically secure communication. Recently, Fu et al. proposed a quantum public key cryptography based on Bell states. However, this protocol cannot guarantee the integrity of information when facing tampering attacks. In this study, we first analyze the security vulnerabilities of the protocol, and then introduces the ideas of decoy states and hash functions to propose an improved quantum public key cryptography protocol. In addition, the use of unordered methods further ensures the security of information. After security analysis, it was found that this protocol can resist tampering attacks and has eavesdropping detection, which has higher security compared to existing protocols.

title: A Joint Denoising Algorithm Combining Improved Ceemdan Decomposition and Wavelet Threshold Processing
authors: Na Li, Wentao Yun, Dong Wang, Kun Tang
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotics, Control and Automation Engineering (RCAE)
abstract: Projectile overload (g-value) is a key parameter for evaluating the in-bore dynamic environment in weapon testing, and its measured signal is susceptible to noise interference. To address this issue, this paper proposes a joint denoising algorithm combining improved CEEMDAN decomposition and wavelet threshold processing, and conducted comparative experiments with single decomposition-reconstruction algorithms and traditional wavelet denoising. The results show that this method effectively eliminates noise and provides reliable data for projectile g-value estimation.

title: HerbalVerse: Virtual Platform to Explore, Learn and Heal with Medicinal Plants
authors: G P Kavya, Vani Harave, Sneha Bharti, Sneha Bharti
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: Preservation and promotion of traditional medicine involve government initiatives like the Ministry of AYUSH, which supports research, integrates these practices. Efforts are also made to document and preserve ethnic and tribal medicinal knowledge of Ayurveda and other traditional medicine practices. “HerbalVerse: A Virtual Platform to Explore, Learn and Heal with Medicinal Plants” is a web-based interactive system designed to enhance awareness of Indian AYUSH medicinal plants through modern digital technologies. The platform addresses the limitations of traditional herbal learning, including low accessibility and minimal user engagement, by integrating immersive 3D plant models supported with multimedia content such as images, audio explanations, and video resources. The system employs the Gemini API for real-time plant identification and natural-language-based summarization, eliminating the need for manual dataset training. Additional features such as guided virtual tours, interactive quizzes, bookmarks, and a voiceassisted learning interface further improve user interaction and knowledge retention. Performance evaluation shows a recognition accuracy of 92.7%, an average response latency of 1.25 seconds, and a user satisfaction score of 4.6/5, demonstrating the platform’s reliability and responsiveness. Overall, HerbalVerse offers a scalable and engaging tool that blends traditional botanical knowledge with artificial intelligence to support learners, researchers, and practitioners in the AYUSH domain.

title: An Assessment of Student Acceptance of the E-TGT Application as an Interactive Learning Innovation in the Digital Era
authors: Anugerah Bagus Wijaya, M. Syaiful Amin, Fiby Nur Afiana, Zanuar Rifai, Ranggi Praharaningtyas Aji, Anisaa Qothrunnada Khoirunnita
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Information Technology, Information Systems and Electrical Engineering (ICITISEE)
abstract: The development of educational technology has encouraged the emergence of various digital learning innovations that emphasize active student engagement. One such innovation is E-TGT (Electronic Team Games Tournament), a gamified learning application that adapts the Teams Games Tournament model to enhance motivation, participation, and interaction in the learning process. This study aims to analyze student acceptance of the E-TGT application in higher education learning activities. The research involved three classes with a total of 129 students who had used the E-TGT application for one semester. A quantitative approach was employed by distributing questionnaires to all respondents, and the collected data were analyzed using descriptive statistics and multiple linear regression to examine the relationships among variables representing ease of use, usefulness, attitudes toward the application, and intention to continue using it. The results indicate that students responded positively to the use of E-TGT, with perceived ease of use significantly influencing both perceived usefulness and attitudes. Perceived usefulness emerged as the dominant factor affecting the intention to continue using the application. Overall, E-TGT is considered an effective and interactive learning innovation that increases student engagement, collaboration, and motivation through educational games and team-based competitions, making it highly relevant for the digital era.

title: Microwave Beamformer Based on Reconfigurable Matching Networks
authors: E. S. Sakomura, J. F. Cunha, F. A. L. Abreu, D. B. Ferreira, D. C. Nascimento
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This paper presents the design of a microwave beamformer that electronically controls the excitations of a phased array over a wide scanning range while maintaining active input impedance matching for all radiators. Closed-form equations are derived for the circuit design, and a synthesis strategy is proposed for its implementation. We introduce two beamforming topologies that control both amplitude and phase: the first requires variable gain components, while the second does not. The circuit eliminates the need for phase shifters, resulting in a low-loss, cost-effective solution based on transmission lines and varactor diodes. To validate the proposed approach, we performed electromagnetic/ circuit co-simulations and conducted experimental bench tests on a fabricated beamformer integrated with a 2.2 GHz linear array of six printed monopoles. The array exhibits significant mutual coupling, leading to a high-mismatch scenario where the active VSWR could exceed 10, corresponding to only about 33% of the incident power being transferred to the antenna at certain beam angles. This challenging condition provided an ideal testbed for the proposed methodology, which successfully achieved the required excitations and impedance matching, resulting in a VSWR better than 2 (over 90% power delivered to the load) across a wide range of beam directions. Finally, extensive tests in an anechoic chamber confirmed the beamformer performance under various operational scenarios.

title: NFTracker: Fine-grained NFT Behavior Traffic Identification over Encrypted Tunnel
authors: Ke Ding, Xiaoyan Hu, Zhuozhuo Shu, Guang Cheng, Ruidong Li, Hua Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cognitive Communications and Networking
abstract: Non-Fungible Tokens (NFTs) have completely changed digital ownership and the decentralized economy. However, their anonymity and encrypted communication, conducted over encrypted tunnels, pose a significant obstacle to regulating illegal activities. Despite advances in encrypted traffic analysis, fine-grained identification of NFT behaviors over encrypted tunnels faces two critical challenges: 1) inexact segmentation of continuous behavioral traffic, and 2) feature homogeneity due to encryption-induced pattern obfuscation. In this paper, we propose NFTracker, a novel framework to identify fine-grained NFT behavioral traffic over encrypted tunnels. We design a traffic segmentation method to isolate behavioral units by leveraging traffic bursts and distribution discrepancies. To combat feature homogeneity, we introduce a sliding-window-based spatio-temporal feature extraction mechanism that captures localized action fingerprints. Furthermore, we utilize a hybrid CNN-Transformer model to integrate spatial patterns and temporal dependencies for robust behavior identification. We evaluate NFTracker on real-world datasets covering five NFT behaviors (browsing, wallet login, purchasing, selling, and minting). Experimental results demonstrate that NFTracker achieves an average F1-score of 0.9212 on identifying NFT behavioral traffic, outperforming state-of-the-art methods in encrypted tunnel scenarios.

title: Online Phase Estimation of Human Oscillatory Motions using Deep Learning
authors: Antonio Grotta, Francesco De Lellis
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Accurately estimating the phase of oscillatory systems is essential for analyzing cyclic activities such as repetitive gestures in human motion. In this work we introduce a learning-based approach for online phase estimation in three-dimensional motion trajectories, using a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network. A calibration procedure is applied to standardize trajectory position and orientation, ensuring invariance to spatial variations. The proposed model is evaluated on motion capture data and further tested in a dynamical system, where the estimated phase is used as input to a reinforcement learning (RL)-based control to assess its impact on the synchronization of a network of Kuramoto oscillators.

title: Performance Analysis of Designed Compact Microstrip Patch Antenna for Wireless Networks
authors: M. Jyothirmai, Mohebbanaaz, B Geetha Rani
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: This research analyze and designs a rectangular microstrip patch antenna using FR4 epoxy substrate. WBANs are progressively important for integrated healthcare monitoring systems because they need to be compact, low-profile, and biocompatible. The proposed antenna operates at the ISM band (5.8 GHz) which is commonly used for medical and wearable devices because of low interference and dependable operation. The antenna is designed using FR4 epoxy which is inexpensive and readily available with a dielectric constant of 4.4. The performance parameters of the antenna which are return loss (S11), gain, bandwidth, radiation pattern, and VSWR are analyzed through simulation using HFSS and other relevant tools. Good size, gain, and impedance matching of the antenna improves the performance of wearable sensors and other WBAN systems. The analysis demonstrates that the proposed design of WBANs operates with adequate efficient, safe, and reliable features as integrated sensors for the system.

title: Implementation of Edge AI/ML Technique for Enhancing Emergency Vehicle Traffic Management
authors: Shruti Upadhyaya, Tejasree Pallati, Gayatri Dinavahi, Bhasker Dappuri
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: Effective emergency vehicle management is essential to human life and property protection in light of India’s quick urbanization and traffic congestion in India. GPS tracking and other conventional deep learning models (CNN, LSTM) are computationally expensive and are not directly applicable to government-agency-associated emergency vehicles. To overcome these challenges, this study suggests an Edge AI/ML-based multimodal detection system integrating YOLOv8 for real-time image classification and CNN-based audio processing for siren detection, which improves speed and accuracy in emergency vehicle detection. The system utilizes LSTM networks for temporal analysis to ensure strong performance in lighting and acoustic conditions. One of the key contributions of this work is the deployment of an optimized, low-latency model on an edge device, allowing real-time traffic signal preemption without needing any changes to the vehicles. The framework puts forward a classification of emergency vehicles into four groups: ambulances, fire trucks, police vehicles, and traffic, along with dynamically optimizing traffic signals through a web-based interface for easy integration with existing infrastructure. Experimental testing shows important advantages over traditional methods, including better detection capability in low-visibility and noisy environments. With intelligent traffic prioritization reducing emergency response times, this system presents a cost-efficient, scalable solution for smart city deployments, eventually leading to better public safety and fewer fatalities.

title: An output reliability assessment method for initiating devices based on fiducial inference
authors: Yeshu Zhang, Huina Mu, Jialin Sun, Shiyao Feng, Xiaojian Yi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Sensing, Diagnostics, Prognostics, and Control
abstract: To address the issues of limited sample size and low accuracy of parameter models in the output reliability assessment of initiating devices, a method based on fiducial inference is proposed. A fiducial inference framework is first established. To verify its effectiveness, numerical simulations are conducted to compare it with the normal statistical tolerance limits method specified in GJB376A-2019. The results show that the proposed method achieves higher estimation accuracy under most sample size conditions. In cases with fewer than 10 samples and a high coefficient of variation in output parameters, the estimation bias is reduced by approximately 20% compared to the traditional method. Moreover, under extremely small sample conditions (n = 3), the fiducial inference method remains stable, demonstrating strong applicability and robustness. It is therefore better suited to scenarios with limited data, effectively mitigating the sample size dependence of conventional methods and providing a novel approach to assessing the output reliability of initiating devices. Its performance is also compared with Bootstrap and Bayesian approximate limit methods to highlight its superiority.

title: Design and Implementation of Low Phase Noise Voltage-Controlled Oscillator Circuit
authors: Chenying Shi
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th International Conference on Power, Intelligent Computing and Systems (ICPICS)
abstract: This paper proposes a design scheme that integrates adaptive genetic algorithm and noise suppression algorithm. The adaptive genetic algorithm can efficiently optimize the key parameters of the VCO circuit by dynamically adjusting the crossover and mutation probabilities and combining the elite retention strategy; the noise suppression fusion algorithm integrates the advantages of phase-locked loop noise suppression and filtering algorithms to achieve coordinated suppression of multiple noise sources. At the circuit design level, a new differential topology is adopted to effectively reduce common-mode noise interference, and the selection of active devices, resonant networks and feedback control circuits are deeply optimized. The model is built and the experiment is carried out using the Cadence Spectre simulation platform. The results show that at a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 k H z}$</tex> offset frequency, the phase noise of the designed VCO reaches <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-145 \text{dBc} / \text{Hz}$</tex>, which is 8 dB lower than the traditional design; the frequency stability is improved to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.2 \times 10^{-6}$</tex>, which is 35 % higher than the traditional solution; and the power consumption is reduced by 18 %. The experimental data fully verified the effectiveness of the innovative algorithm and circuit design, which not only provided a new path for the development of high-performance signal sources, but also laid a technical foundation for the application expansion of low phase noise VCO in the fields of communication, radar, etc., which has important theoretical and practical significance for promoting the development of related industries.

title: Fully Automated SAM for Single-source Domain Generalization in Medical Image Segmentation
authors: Huanli Zhuo, Leilei Ma, Haifeng Zhao, Shiwei Zhou, Dengdi Sun, Yanping Fu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Although SAM-based single-source domain generalization models for medical image segmentation can mitigate the impact of domain shift on the model in cross-domain scenarios, these models still face two major challenges. First, the segmentation of SAM is highly dependent on domain-specific expert-annotated prompts, which prevents SAM from achieving fully automated medical image segmentation and therefore limits its application in clinical settings. Second, providing poor prompts (such as bounding boxes that are too small or too large) to the SAM prompt encoder can mislead SAM into generating incorrect mask results. Therefore, we propose the FA-SAM, a single-source domain generalization framework for medical image segmentation that achieves fully automated SAM. FA-SAM introduces two key innovations: an Auto-prompted Generation Model (AGM) branch equipped with a Shallow Feature Uncertainty Modeling (SUFM) module, and an Image-Prompt Embedding Fusion (IPEF) module integrated into the SAM mask decoder. Specifically, AGM models the uncertainty distribution of shallow features through the SUFM module to generate bounding box prompts for the target domain, enabling fully automated segmentation with SAM. The IPEF module integrates multiscale information from SAM image embeddings and prompt embeddings to capture global and local details of the target object, enabling SAM to mitigate the impact of poor prompts. Extensive experiments on publicly available prostate and fundus vessel datasets validate the effectiveness of FA-SAM and highlight its potential to address the above challenges.

title: Integration of BVG-LS into a Deep Neural Network Architecture Designed for EEG Signal Classification
authors: Takuto Fukushima, Ryusuke Miyamoto
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: The present work enhanced the classification accuracy of motor imagery (MI) based on EEG signals using a novel deep neural network (DNN) architecture that integrated InternImage and ST-pooling to capture spatiotemporal features. While this architecture outperformed existing methods in classification accuracy, the validation loss indicates overfitting during training. We introduce a bias-variance guided layer selection (BVG-LS) strategy into the fine-tuning process to address this issue. This approach adaptively adjusts the number and selection of layers updated during fine-tuning, replacing the conventional single-layer update with a more effective multi-layer configuration guided by BVG-LS. Experimental evaluation on the cross-individual validation task using the PhysioNet EEG Motor Movement/Imagery dataset showed that the accuracy of two-, three-, and four-class classification were improved to 89.06%, 81.13%, and 70.90%, respectively, surpassing the performance of existing fine-tuning techniques, including full fine-tuning.

title: PyGress: Tool for Analyzing the Progression of Code Proficiency in Python OSS Projects
authors: Rujiphart Charatvaraphan, Bunradar Chatchaiyadech, Thitirat Sukijprasert, Chaiyong Ragkhitwetsagul, Morakot Choetkiertikul, Raula Gaikovina Kula, Thanwadee Sunetnanta, Kenichi Matsumoto
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Assessing developer proficiency in open-source software (OSS) projects is essential for understanding project dynamics, especially for expertise. This paper presents "PyGress", a web-based tool designed to automatically evaluate and visualize Python code proficiency using pycefr, a Python code proficiency analyzer. By submitting a GitHub repository link, the system extracts commit histories, analyzes source code proficiency across CEFR-aligned levels (A1-C2), and generates visual summaries of individual and project-wide proficiency. The PyGress tool visualizes per-contributor proficiency distribution and tracks project code proficiency progression over time. PyGress offers an interactive way to explore contributor coding levels in Python OSS repositories. The video demonstration of the PyGress tool can be found at https://youtu.be/hxoeK-ggcWk, and the source code of the tool is publicly available at https://github.com/MUICT-SERU/PyGress.

title: FilMBot: A High-Speed Soft Parallel Robotic Micromanipulator
authors: Jiangkun Yu, Houari Bettahar, Hakan Kandemir, Quan Zhou
abstract: Soft robotic manipulators are generally slow despite their great adaptability, resilience, and compliance. This limitation also extends to current soft robotic micromanipulators. Here, we introduce FilMBot, a 3-DOF film-based, electromagnetically actuated, soft kinematic robotic micromanipulator achieving speeds up to 2117 °/s and 2456 °/s in α and β angular motions, with corresponding linear velocities of 1.61 m/s and 1.92 m/s using a 4-cm needle end-effector, 0.54 m/s along the Z axis, and 1.57 m/s during Z-axis morph switching. The robot can reach ∼1.50 m/s in path-following tasks, with an operational bandwidth below ∼30 Hz, and remains responsive at 50 Hz. It demonstrates high precision (∼6.3 μm, or ∼0.05% of its workspace) in path-following tasks, with precision remaining largely stable across frequencies. The novel combination of the low-stiffness soft kinematic film structure and strong electromagnetic actuation in FilMBot opens new avenues for soft robotics. Furthermore, its simple construction and inexpensive, readily accessible components could broaden the application of micromanipulators beyond current academic and professional users.

title: Design of a PMSM Demagnetization Fault Diagnosis Scheme Using SOGI to Extract Fault Features
authors: Kun He, Ng Jiunn Yea, Shamini Janasekaran, Bin Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th International Conference on Power, Intelligent Computing and Systems (ICPICS)
abstract: This article seeks to propose the design of a fault diagnosis scheme used in the detection and the demagnetization of faults found along Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motors (PMSMs). The proposed design will seek to leverage on the prospects of the Second-Order Generalized Integrator (SOGI). As found in this article, accurate systems on fault detection and extraction are critical in the process of demagnetizing faults through PMSM, a process that ensures a higher level of accuracy is reached during the diagnosis. To achieve this, a design model is used in the extraction of faults through the use of SOGI and driven by the capacity to increase precision and reliability in identifying signals during an operational process remains key. Real-time systems of monitoring of the PMSM system parameters will in this case be considered through a SOGI model to enhance the fault detection process. An analysis of the systems extracted features through the use of advanced diagnostic algorithms in the identification and the quantification of the demagnetization process was conducted. Findings established that the proposed model widely relies on the SOGI in enhancing as well as improving the accuracy and levels of detecting demagnetized processes as opposed to the traditional model. This factor therefore enhances the process of fault detection while on the other hand cutting down on downtimes. The design remains efficient in motor fault operations and diagnosis models, providing an efficient and robust alternative to improving the reliability and longevity of the PMSM system.

title: Dealing with Limitations of DGA Dataset using Gaussian Process for Transformer Identification Faults
authors: Muhammad Akmal A. Putra, Muhammad Rafi Sudrajat, Suwarno, Rahman Azis Prasojo
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on High Voltage Engineering and Power Systems (ICHVEPS)
abstract: Early fault detection is critical to enhancing transformer reliability and preventing system failures that could result in substantial losses. One primary approach to diagnosing transformer faults is using Dissolved Gas Analysis (DGA). However, the limitations of raw DGA data present a significant challenge in developing accurate and reliable machine learning (ML) models. This study proposes the use of the Gaussian Process Classifier (GPC) method to address data availability limitations in ML modeling, with data validation from IEC TC-10 and other real-world cases. The GPC method not only achieves higher prediction accuracy for smaller data but also provides uncertainty levels for its predictions. This feature offers a key advantage over other ML models, which typically do not provide true uncertainty quantification. Through comparative analysis with models such as Random Forest, Support Vector Machine, and Neural Networks, the study demonstrates that GPC outperforms other methods in scenarios with limited data and offers additional insights through uncertainty quantification. This capability makes GPC a more reliable solution for transformer fault diagnosis, thereby enhancing decision-making confidence in the field, where quick decisions are paramount. The findings of this study are expected to significantly contribute to the development of more reliable prediction systems while paving the way for broader applications of the GPC approach in machine learning-based diagnostics.

title: Obsessive compulsive disorder diagnosing based on gramian angular field combing hemodynamic response features measured by functional near-infrared spectroscopy
authors: Mingxi Yang, Di Wu, Haoran Liu, Daifa Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: The diagnosis of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) often relies on clinical interviews and other subjective assessments. Functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) is a non-invasive optical technique widely used to monitor brain activity and assist clinicians in objective brain function evaluation. The advancement of time-series-to-image transformation techniques has opened new pathways for integrating fNIRS with deep learning; however, these methods often suffer from the loss of hemodynamic response function (HRF) information. To address this challenge, we propose a framework for converting fNIRS time-series data into virtual images while preserving HRF activation information. This framework utilizes globally min-max normalized Gramian Angular Fields (GAF) for virtual image transformation, which are subsequently used in deep learning classification models. In cross-validation experiments, the GAF virtual images incorporating HRF information achieved the highest average classification accuracy of 86.7%. Our findings indicate that GAF virtual images integrated with HRF features provide a novel approach for fNIRS-based OCD classification research, further promoting the clinical application of fNIRS technology.

title: Towards Visual-Fatigue-Free BCI with Imperceptible Visual Evoked Potentials (I-VEP)
authors: Milán András Fodor, Ivan Volosyak
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: A Brain–computer interface (BCI) enables direct control of external devices through neural activity. Among BCI paradigms, visual evoked potentials (VEPs) are widely used because they harness the brain’s response to visual stimuli to deliver an intuitive and inclusive control interface. However, these systems typically rely on low-frequency flickering stimuli to evoke strong neural responses, which can cause discomfort and fatigue. While previous attempts have sought to mitigate this discomfort, eliminating it entirely would be ideal. This could be achieved with high-frequency flickering operating above the critical fusion frequency threshold, which is invisible to the human eye yet still evokes a distinct neural imprint. While this neural response is distinguishable from that of a non-flickering stimulus, reliably differentiating between two different high-frequency stimuli remains challenging.Our novel Imperceptible VEP (I-VEP) paradigm combines imperceptible high-frequency flicker segments with static (non-flickering) intervals to create patterns analogous to steady-state VEP (SSVEP) and code-modulated VEP (cVEP). From this paradigm, we define two variants: Imperceptible Steady-State VEP (I-SSVEP) and Imperceptible Code-Modulated VEP (I-cVEP). Our initial I-cVEP experiments demonstrate its feasibility, achieving a mean bit-wise accuracy of over 92% across 27 participants. These findings may represent a significant first step toward fully comfortable visual-stimulus BCIs, enabling broader adoption and improved usability.

title:
