                    : An Extensible Framework for LLM-enhanced Scratch Static Code Analysis
authors: Benedikt Fein, Florian Obermüller, Gordon Fraser
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Large language models (LLMS) have become an essential tool to support developers using traditional text-based programming languages, but the graphical notation of the block-based Scratch programming environment inhibits the use of LLMs. To overcome this limitation, we propose the LitterBox<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">+</sup> framework that extends the Scratch static code analysis tool LitterBox with the generative abilities of LLMs. By converting block-based code to a textual representation suitable for LLMs, LitterBox<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">+</sup>allows users to query LLMs about their programs, about quality issues reported by LitterBox, and it allows generating code fixes. Besides offering a programmatic API for these functionalities, LitterBox<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">+</sup> also extends the Scratch user interface to make these functionalities available directly in the environment familiar to learners. The framework is designed to be easily extensible with other prompts, LLM providers, and new features combining the program analysis capabilities of LitterBox with the generative features of LLMs. We provide a screencast demonstrating the tool at https://youtu.be/RZ6E0xgrIgQ.

title: A Game Theory-Based Proactive Defense Mechanism for Link Prediction Attacks
authors: Zhihao Xu, Dawen Huang
publish: 2025 2nd International Symposium on AI and Cybersecurity (ISAICS)
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) has brought significant convenience and efficiency to society, yet it also introduces unprecedented security challenges. Among these, link prediction attacks represent a major threat. Since such attacks do not involve destructive actions-such as data injection, tampering, or flooding-they generate no detectable anomalous signals, making them difficult to identify using conventional intrusion detection mechanisms. To address this issue, this paper proposes a game-theoretic proactive defense mechanism. By obfuscating the network’s topological information, our method prevents attackers from accurately inferring the network structure, thereby leading them to erroneous link predictions. Experimental results demonstrate the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed approach, confirming its strong defensive performance against link prediction attacks.

title: The Chamber Assistant: A Language-Model Approach to Industrial Fault Correction and Documentation
authors: Nandan Shrinivas Chebbi, Roshan Balaji Mahashabde, K.R Usha Rani, Pratik Barve
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Intelligent Signal Processing and Effective Communication Technologies (INSPECT)
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) are transforming industrial R&D labs to handle complex problem-solving, documentation, and data analysis. This paper introduces the Chamber Assistant, a smart assistant tailored for research labs. It leverages small and large language models that are trained on equipment manuals to answer technical queries and automate routine documentation. This system supports both online and offline use and features a browser-based interface for ease of use. LLMs such as LLaMA 3 and TinyLLaMA were fine-tuned on a custom industrial equipment dataset. The validation loss for both models was less than 10%, and the BLEU (Bilingual Evaluation Understudy) score was 0.91 and 0.95 for TinyLLaMA and LLaMA 3. Our results show high accuracy on test questions and demonstrate strong alignment with real-world documentation and fault correction, making this approach practical, costeffective, and privacy-friendly for sensitive lab environments.

title: The Effectiveness of Implementing Android's TalkBack Screen Reader and Braille-Based Gestures on Android Application in Facilitating Visually Impaired Users in Music Learning
authors: Samantha Michelle, Sonya Rapinta Manalu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Data and Software Engineering (ICoDSE)
abstract: Visually impaired individuals often face significant barriers to explore their talents due to the lack of accessible learning tools. This research addresses this problem by proposing and evaluating a mobile-based music learning application designed to facilitate music education for blind users. The application development implemented Android's built-in TalkBack screen reader and Braille-based hand gestures to minimize reliance on visual guidance. The aim of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of the assistive technology in improving accessibility and music learning for visually impaired users. Two main modules are included in the application: Braille music notation learning and virtual piano simulator. The development process follows the Research and Development (R&D) methodology using the Prototype Model of the Software Development Life Cycle and evaluated through heuristic based methods based on WCAG 2.2 principles with a task-based case study tested on a blind pianist who never learned Braille music notation before, gathering the feedback from the real blind musician on how the application interaction works. The results showed high learnability and usability with 26 % time saving in task performance across iterations and a SUS score of 82.5 that categorized as “Excellent”. The study confirms that the integration of Braille-based gestures with standard accessibility features is a highly effective approach for creating an intuitive and empowering music learning experience for visually impaired users.

title: Research on Local End-to-End Learning Model for Autonomous Driving
authors: Shuo Song, Yu Chen, Ying Zhang, Ning Ma, Zhenghan Li, Yun Feng
publish: 2025 9th CAA International Conference on Vehicular Control and Intelligence (CVCI)
abstract: To address the problems of low inter-module coordination efficiency, information transmission delay, and insufficient environmental adaptability in traditional autonomous driving systems, this paper proposes an integrated decision-planning-control end-to-end learning method based on a Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) framework. This method uses a Variational Autoencoder (VAE) to extract compact latent representations from high-dimensional visual inputs and integrates it with vehicle state data and navigation instructions to construct a unified state representation space. On this basis, a Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) algorithm is used to achieve a direct end-to-end mapping from raw perception input to low-level vehicle control commands. A set of test tasks covering various complex traffic scenarios was designed on the CARLA simulation platform for system evaluation. Experimental results show that the proposed model demonstrates excellent performance in core driving tasks such as lane keeping and dynamic obstacle avoidance. This paper proposes an end-to-end learning model that integrates VAE-based multi-source state representation with a PPO optimization framework. Compared with existing approaches that rely solely on single-visual input or modular architectures, the proposed model demonstrates significant advantages in stability, convergence speed, and adaptability to complex scenarios.

title: Modeling and Statistical Characterization of Large-Scale Automotive Radar Networks
authors: Mohammad Taha Shah, Gourab Ghatak, Ankit Kumar, Shobha Sundar Ram
abstract: The impact of discrete clutter and co-channel interference on the performance of automotive radar networks has been studied using stochastic geometry, in particular, by leveraging Poisson point processes (PPPs). However, such characterization does not take into account the impact of street geometry and the fact that the location of the automotive radars are restricted to the streets as their domain rather than the entire Euclidean plane. In addition, the structure of the streets may change drastically as a vehicle moves out of a city center towards the suburban areas. Consequently, not only the radar performance change but also the radar parameters and protocols must be adapted for optimum performance. In this paper, we propose and characterize line and Cox process-based street and point models to analyze large-scale automotive radar networks. We consider the classical Poisson line process (PLP) and the newly introduced Binomial line process (BLP) model to emulate the streets, and the corresponding PPP-based Cox process to emulate the vehicular nodes. In particular, the BLP model effectively considers the spatial variation of street geometry across different parts of the city. We derive the effective interference set experienced by an automotive radar, the statistics of distance to interferers, and characterize the detection probability of the ego radar as a function of street and vehicle density. Finally, leveraging the real-world data on urban streets and vehicle density across different cities of the world, we present how the radar performance varies in different parts of the city as well as across different times of the day. Thus, our study equips network operators and automotive manufacturers with system design insights to optimize automotive radar networks.

title: Research on Remote Time-Frequency Traceability Based on GNSS Common-View Time Comparisone
authors: Chen Yuyang, Zeng Lingjian, Huang Wuping, Kang Xin, Wang Rui
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th International Conference on Power, Intelligent Computing and Systems (ICPICS)
abstract: In recent years, with the continuous advancement of related fields such as communications, navigation, astronomy, energy, and precision manufacturing, the development of time-frequency metrology has assumed increasing significance. To minimize errors in remote time-frequency traceability, enhance the stability of traceability, and foster the development of emerging technologies for remote time-frequency traceability, this study takes the established remote time-frequency traceability system as its research subject. By leveraging the GNSS common-view comparison technique, the research achieves time comparison between the remote time-frequency traceability system and the global navigation satellite system. Finally, through data analysis of satellite comparison observation files, the feasibility of remote time-frequency traceability technology based on GNSS common-view comparison is validated, providing a reference for remote time-frequency traceability and comparison techniques in related disciplines.

title: Clarifying Semantics of In-Context Examples for Unit Test Generation
authors: Chen Yang, Lin Yang, Ziqi Wang, Dong Wang, Jianyi Zhou, Junjie Chen
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Recent advances in large language models (LLMs) have enabled promising performance in unit test generation through in-context learning (ICL). However, the quality of in-context examples significantly influences the effectiveness of generated tests—poorly structured or semantically unclear test examples often lead to suboptimal outputs. In this paper, we propose CLAST, a novel technique that systematically refines unit tests to improve their semantic clarity, thereby enhancing their utility as in-context examples. The approach decomposes complex tests into logically clearer ones and improves semantic clarity through a combination of program analysis and LLM-based rewriting. We evaluated CLAST on four open-source and three industrial projects. The results demonstrate that CLAST largely outperforms UTgen, the state-of-the-art refinement technique, in both preserving test effectiveness and enhancing semantic clarity. Specifically, CLAST fully retains the original effectiveness of unit tests, while UTgen reduces compilation success rate (CSR), pass rate (PR), test coverage (Cov), and mutation score (MS) by an average of 12.90%, 35.82%, 4.65%, and 5.07%, respectively. Over 85.33% of participants in our user study preferred the semantic clarity of CLAST-refined tests. Notably, incorporating CLAST-refined tests as examples effectively improves ICL-based unit test generation approaches such as RAGGen and TELPA, resulting in an average increase of 25.97% in CSR, 28.22% in PR, and 45.99% in Cov for generated tests, compared to incorporating UTgen-refined tests. The insights from the follow-up user study not only reinforce CLAST’s potential impact in software testing practice but also illuminate avenues for future research.

title: Evaluating the Suitability of MQTT and HTTP for ESP32-Based IoT Architectures
authors: Tarun Sudheer Kartha, Abhaykrishnan Namboothiri P J, Sana K S, Mridhul Ramesh, Raunak Dev, Jayasree K R, Balaji Hariharan, Liya M L
publish: 2025 International Conference on Robotics and Mechatronics (ICRM)
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) makes it possible for physical objects with sensors, software, electronics, and networking capabilities to connect seamlessly, allowing for effective data sharing and remote control for a variety of applications. Choosing the right communication protocol is essential to ensuring low latency, scalability, and adaptability as IoT use increases in sectors including home automation, industrial monitoring, and government security. The efficiency, usability, and appropriateness for resource-constrained contexts of the MQTT and HTTP protocols are the main points of comparison and evaluation in this study. In order to provide useful suggestions for protocol selection catered to certain IoT deployment situations, the research takes into account important trade-offs pertaining to latency, modularity, and system adaptability. The results highlight the significance of striking a balance between high performance and constrained computational and energy resources, providing insightful information for improving IoT data transport. This study advances a better knowledge of IoT communication issues and facilitates well-informed decision-making for dependable and effective IoT system design by outlining the advantages and disadvantages of both protocols.

title: Research on Intelligent Identification of Transmission Tower Bolts Using Improved YOLO Algorithm
authors: Kai Guo, Zhong Gu, Pengyun Jia
publish: 2025 IEEE 7th International Conference on Power, Intelligent Computing and Systems (ICPICS)
abstract: Transmission tower bolt is a key connecting component, its state directly affects the safe and stable operation of power system. Aiming at the low efficiency and accuracy of traditional identification methods and the limitations of existing deep learning model in micro target identification, this paper proposes an intelligent identification method for transmission tower bolts with improved YOLOv5s. The experimental results show that the improved model has achieved excellent performance in the transmission tower bolt identification task, with identification accuracy of 98.5%, recall rate of 98.9%, and average accuracy (mAP @ 0.5) up to 99.2%, which was increased by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8.3 \%, 9.1 \%$</tex> and 8.7% respectively compared with the original YOLOv5s model. This method provides efficient and reliable technical support for intelligent inspection of power system, and has important engineering application value.

title: A Robust Angle-Uncertain Hybrid Beamforming and Quantized Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces Refinement Method for Massive Multiple-Input Multiple-Output Systems
authors: M. Satish Kumar, S. Srikanth, S. Vijayashaarathi, Suma Srinath, G. Satish
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: In this era, the terahertz massive Multiple-Input Multiple-Output (MIMO) systems demand robust Hybrid analog-digital Beam Forming (HBF) techniques that assists to resolve the challenges of severe path loss and hardware constraints. In particular, the conventional Angular-Based HBF (AB-HBF) and multi-Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces (RIS)assisted designs depend on accurate angular information and computationally high optimization which restrict the applicability to dynamic or resource-constrained deployments. Therefore, this research proposes Angle-Error-Resilient Hybrid Beamforming with Quantized RIS Refinement (AER-HBF-Q) which is an effective hybrid beamforming framework. Initially, an angle-error-resilient RF beamforming strategy is introduced where individual RF beam is designed over a bounded angular uncertainty that assists to mitigate the effect of Angle-of-Arrival (AoA) and Angle-of-Departure (AoD) estimation errors. Thereby, this enhances directional robustness without increasing hardware cost. Then, a quantized local-search RIS refinement algorithm is developed to optimize RIS phase shifts that incorporates a deterministic search over four low-resolution quantized phase values. Hence, the proposed AER-HBF-Q framework is applicable to both single-RIS and multiRIS systems that provides substantial gains in achievable rate with negligible computational overhead.

title: An Electric Taxi-to-Base Assignment System Using Path Relinking and Ejection Chain Optimization Computational Intelligence
authors: Dzikri Muhammad Raditya Putra, I Gusti Bagus Baskara Nugraha, Arry Akhmad Arman
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Information Technology, Information Systems and Electrical Engineering (ICITISEE)
abstract: The use of electric vehicles in society is increasing, including in the field of public transportation such as taxis. However, the shift to use electric vehicles raises the challenge of battery constraints in public transportation operations. One of the challenges is the challenge of assigning taxis to bases based on certain parameters to optimize the taxi-to-base assignment configuration with battery constraints. This is because some companies do not allow their drivers to recharge outside the depot unless it is necessary to do so. In addition, optimal assignment is very important to increase the conversion rate, which is the number of orders that can be handled by taxis at each base. This study proposes a EV taxi to base assignment system based on Problem Solving Agent through Path Relinking and Ejection Chain (PREC) algorithm to address these issues. The system considers various dynamic variables such as vehicle battery level, estimated travel duration, cumulative order intensity along the route, and the order demand at each base. Experimental simulations demonstrate that the proposed system significantly improves the base-level order conversion rate when compared to manual direct assignments performed by human operators. The evaluation was conducted using SimPy-based simulations across multiple base scenarios, including a case study in the city of Bandung. The results show that the proposed system consistently outperforms manual direct assignments performed by human operators with higher base conversion rates and ensure compliance with battery constraints for each assignment.

title: Design and Verification of a 16-Bit Multi-Slave SPI Protocol in System Verilog
authors: S Priyadarshini, Neha. S. Hosamath, Subodh Kumar Panda, D Smitha Gayathri, S Bindu, P Rekha
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: For high-performance embedded and System-onChip (SoC) platforms that interact with peripherals like sensors, memory devices, and data converters, reliable serial communication is crucial. The design, cycle-accurate modeling, and functional verification of a 16-bit, multi-slave System Verilog Serial Peripheral Interface (SPI) controller are presented in this work. Full-duplex communication, variable clock polarity (CPOL) and phase (CPHA), and the ability to choose up to three slave devices are all supported by the design. Power, area, gate count, and initial timing behavior could all be quantitatively analyzed thanks to the design's synthesis using Cadence Genus and simulation in the Cadence RTL environment. To ensure proper master-slave data transfer, a guided System Verilog testbench was created, and functional validation for SPI Mode-0 operation was shown. The implementation offers a comprehensive RTL-to-synthesis design path appropriate for incorporation into embedded subsystems, even though the current verification does not cover all SPI modes or corner-case scenarios. The study lays the groundwork for future upgrades incorporating more sophisticated verification and wider protocol support while highlighting useful factors in SPI controller development.

title: Cooperative Consensus Q-Learning for Micro Multi-Agent Tumor Targeting
authors: Neshat Elhami Fard, Behnaz Merikhi, Rastko R. Selmic
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: This paper introduces a cooperative consensus Q-learning method that targets tumors using micro multi-agent reinforcement learning (MMARL) systems. The micro-agents in this system navigate toward cancerous tumors autonomously in a simulated 2-D vascular environment using Q-learning and cooperative position consensus. In this proposed method, the agents share Q-values and align their movements with each other. Employing this strategy results in coordinated behavior. Under bounded perturbations, theoretical analyses show convergence guarantees for Q-value and cooperative position consensuses. The simulation results demonstrate that this offered technique boosts convergence speed, improves stability, and enhances cumulative rewards compared to the standard consensus method, highlighting its significance for biomedical applications.

title: Programmers’ Visual Attention on Function Call Graphs During Code Summarization
authors: Samantha McLoughlin, Zachary Karas, Robert Wallace, Aakash Bansal, Collin McMillan, Yu Huang
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: This paper studies programmer visual attention on code as it relates to underlying function call graphs during code summarization. Programmer visual attention refers to where people look when performing a software engineering task, and code summarization is the task of writing a natural language description about a section of source code. Prior work has studied programmers’ visual attention during code summarization, with the vast majority of research effort placed on details in single functional units of code. There have not been any techniques developed to understand code comprehension at the project level due to the difficulty of this task, despite the nature of most real-world methods as embedded within complex project context. This paper focuses on the visual attention paid to the call graph context in which a method sits. We analyze visual attention coverage of call graphs with graph-based metrics, such as the depth that programmers traverse or the amount of coverage they attain. We use these metrics, among other means, to reevaluate an existing dataset from a previous eye-tracking study of programmers (n = 10) that considered basic properties of programmer visual attention in a project context. We then created a new dataset (n = 12) using the same procedures specifically for this paper, resulting in a total of 88 hours of recorded visual behavior on source code. We used our proposed metrics to analyze how participants’ visual strategies correlated with their code summary quality, and confidence in their summaries. Interestingly, we found that higher coverage of the call graph was associated with decreases in both summary quality and participants’ confidence.

title: Latency-minimized Computation Offloading in 3C Manufacturing Workshops
authors: Yanan Liu, Jing Bi, Ziqi Wang, Junqi Zhang, Haitao Yuan, Jia Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: With the rapid advancement and integration of Internet of Things technology into manufacturing, industrial workshops in computer, communication, and consumer electronics (3C) manufacturing are increasingly confronted with complex computational tasks during production. However, the limited hardware resources and computational capabilities of local devices often hinder efficient task execution. Computational offloading offers a viable solution by allowing complex computational tasks to be processed on either edge or cloud servers, enhancing the efficiency of computational task handling in production environments. A critical challenge lies in optimizing task offloading among local devices, edge servers, and cloud servers to maximize production efficiency while ensuring reasonable task scheduling. To address this challenge, this work proposes a flexible computational offloading strategy based on an edge-cloud architecture in a smartphone manufacturing workshop. First, a framework for edge-cloud workshop manufacturing is constructed, integrating various smartphone production devices. Based on the edge-cloud framework, a constrained optimization problem for computation offloading is formulated, using latency as the objective in industrial production settings. A time consumption model is employed to optimize computational time, and a novel scheduling strategy named Ivy-Genetic Evolution Algorithm (IGEA) is designed to solve the scheduling problem. The IGEA integrates genetic operators into the Ivy Algorithm to introduce a randomness strategy. Experimental results demonstrate that IGEA significantly outperforms state-of-the-art approaches in optimizing production efficiency.

title: Training-Control-as-Code: Towards a declarative solution to control training
authors: Padmanabha V. Seshadri, Harikrishnan Balagopal, Mehant Kammakomati, Ashok Pon Kumar, Dushyant Behl
publish: 2025 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering (ASE)
abstract: Training-as-a-service platforms facilitate users to deploy pre-configured Generative AI training jobs as batch workloads. The immutability of configuration offers minimal flexibility to dynamically adapt to training progress. Existing approaches invariably involve manually monitoring training progress on a dashboard, and the stop-reconfigure-restart of training does not scale well with number of experiments. Relying on pre-configuration, wastes computational resources and makes debugging of training jobs difficult. We address this gap through our training-control-as-code paradigm, which allows users to run user-defined code to analyze the training state and intervene to flag anomalies and save resource wastage. Our framework TrAC offers a declarative interface to allow for declaring desired control and for reusing it at scale. Using real-world open-source data and models we provide estimates on the savings in time and resource due to TrAC. We also provide demo video: https://youtu.be/RmhBfFjd1oA and code: https://github.com/foundation-model-stack/fms-hf-tuning/blob/main/examples/trainercontroller_configs/Readme.md

title: Machine Learning for Supermarket Sales and Customer Segmentation
authors: Amala Rajan, Nouf Essa, Noora Mohammed, Oasha Rashed, Alain Tcheukam Siwe, Rejitha Ravikumar, Mohammed Hassouna
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Information Technology Trends (ITT)
abstract: The growth of retail data has made it possible to use machine learning to better understand customer behavior and improve decision-making. This paper examines supermarket sales data and applies a combination of descriptive and inferential statistics, regression, classification, and clustering to generate business insights. A descriptive analysis was used to summarize key patterns in sales and customer activity, while inferential tests highlighted significant relationships between factors, such as gender and customer type. Regression analysis indicated that multiple linear regression achieved very high predictive accuracy ($R^{2} \approx 0.9999$) compared to simple regression. In the classification stage, the accuracy of models improved after data cleaning, with Naïve Bayes giving the best result at 60%. Clustering methods, including hierarchical and K-Means, revealed groups of customers and products that suggested practical strategies for targeted marketing and inventory planning. Overall, the study demonstrates that combining different machine learning techniques provides a fuller understanding of supermarket sales and customer patterns, offering useful guidance for managers in planning and decision-making.

title: Globally Balanced Multidimensional Resource Allocation for Data Center Optical Networks Secured by Quantum Key Distribution
authors: Yijia Zheng, Yuan Cao, Xiaoyu Wang
abstract: In this paper, we propose a globally balanced multidimensional resource allocation (GB-MRA) algorithm for data center optical networks secured by quantum key distribution. Compared to the benchmark algorithm, the GB-MRA algorithm can increase the success probability of cloud-edge service requests by 24.42%, while improving the utilization of multidimensional resources such as computing, wavelength, and key resources.

title: Numerical Investigation of ZrN-ITO Coated Photonic Crystal Fiber Based Plasmonic Refractive Index Sensor
authors: Fardous Mahmud, Samiul Hasan, Hemal Sharma, Shahriar Haque Kanon, Emranul Haque, Feroz Ahmed
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical Information and Communication Technology (EICT)
abstract: Recent developments in surface plasmon resonancebased sensor technology have made it possible to achieve highly accurate sensing without the need for invasive or destructive methods. In this work, a hybrid sensor based on SPR phenomena and photonic crystal fiber (PCF) is introduced, employing a combination of zirconium nitride (ZrN) with indium tin oxide (ITO) for refractive index (RI) monitoring. The device functions effectively across a broad refractive index spectrum of 1.28-1.42. The maximum wavelength sensitivity reaches 5000 nm per RIU, along with an amplitude sensitivity of 115 per RIU, marking the highest performance benchmarks reported for ZrN-based PCF sensors in this RI range without the use of noble plasmonic metals. The architecture features a dual-side polished D-shaped geometry integrated with two analyte microchambers. To optimize the confinement loss (CL) spectra, the thickness of the ZrN layer deposited on top of the ITO was systematically evaluated. Numerical simulations were executed using the finite element method (FEM). ZrN is a durable alternative to conventional plasmonic materials such as gold or silver owing to its superior chemical and thermal stabilities and potent resonance effects. Additionally, an interfacial ITO thin film was employed to improve the adhesion of ZrN and enhance plasmonic excitation. The findings of this study underscore the suitability of $\mathbf{Z r N}$ for broad-spectrum RI sensing in PCF-based SPR configurations.

title: SocializeChat: A GPT-Based AAC Tool Grounded in Personal Memories to Support Social Communication
authors: Wei Xiang, Yunkai Xu, Yuyang Fang, Zhuyu Teng, Zhaoqu Jiang, Beijia Hu, Jinguo Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Elderly people with speech impairments often face challenges in engaging in meaningful social communication, particularly when using Augmentative and Alternative Communication (AAC) tools that primarily address basic needs. Moreover, effective chats often rely on personal memories, which is hard to extract and reuse. We introduce SocializeChat, an AAC tool that generates sentence suggestions by drawing on users’ personal memory records. By incorporating topic preference and interpersonal closeness, the system reuses past experience and tailors suggestions to different social contexts and conversation partners. SocializeChat not only leverages past experiences to support interaction, but also treats conversations as opportunities to create new memories, fostering a dynamic cycle between memory and communication. A user study shows its potential to enhance the inclusivity and relevance of AAC-supported social interaction.

title: A 30.28-151.42TFLOPS/W@FP8 Training Accelerator with Hybrid Compute-in-Memory and Workload Scheduling for Edge AI Applications
authors: Mingxuan Li, Qinzhe Zhi, Zhaoyang Zhang, Fangyuan Dong, Wenjie Ren, Jun Yang, Le Ye, Xin Si, Tianyu Jia
abstract: Deploying AI models, e.g., Transformer and CNN, at edge is an inevitable trend and has exhibited outstanding performance in many fields. Compared to inference, edge training brings key advantages in privacy and customization. Previously inference [1–6] and training [7–9] accelerators have been presented, in which compute-inmemory (CIM) [1], [10] has been widely adopted to improve hardware efficiency. However, prior work has not fully addressed the edge training challenges from perspectives of hardware utilization, training accuracy, and computation efficiency, as shown in Fig. 1. First, there is significant unbalanced computation operations exists across different training steps, i.e. forward propagation and backward propagation, leading to <40 % hardware utilization on traditional accelerator architecture, i.e. a CPU with attached NPU. Second, on-chip memory is quite limited for training ($\gt 2.4 \times$ memory requirement than inference), resulting in aggressive sparsity and quantization with considerable accuracy loss, e.g. 9.71% accuracy loss for ViT-base model using FP8. Third, memory access dataflow for existing CIM is not efficient, as weight-stationary CIM consumes significant power, e.g. 42%, on input memory access.

title: Learning Corruption-Invariant Components and Cross-Modal Correspondence for Unsupervised Visible-Infrared Person Re-Identification
authors: Long Chen, Rui Sun, Xuebin Wang, Guoxi Huang, Jingjing Wu, Wei Jia
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Unsupervised Visible-Infrared Person Re-Identification (US-VI-ReID) has great potential prospects because it does not require label information. However, corrupted pedestrian images collected due to corruption factors in real-world scenarios (e.g., noise, blur, and weather changes) largely limit the scalability of US-VI-ReID. In this paper, we explore the robustness of US-VI-ReID for the first time and propose a Multi-Granularity Spatial-Frequency Prototype Learning (MSPL) framework. The framework mainly consists of Multi-Channel Soft Augmentation (MSA), Robust Frequency Domain Feature Learning (RFL) module and Cross-modal Spatial-Frequency Prototype Matching (CSPM). Specifically, the MSA alleviates the sensitivity of model to color and abnormal samples through rich channel combinations and soft erasing. Subsequently, the RFL performs deep global filtering and amplitude attention compensated InstanceNorm to complete frequency and style modulation, concentrating on degradation-robust frequency content. Finally, the CSPM is designed to achieve multi-granularity prototype contrastive learning on cluster level and view level, then conduct cross-modal matching of multi-granularity spatial-frequency prototypes, thus establishing robust label association. With the above modules, our proposed framework can learn corruption-invariant feature components and generate robust cross-modal correspondence from unlabeled cross-modal images. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our MSPL outperforms other state-of-the-art methods by a large margin on the challenging SYSU-MM01-C and RegDB-C, while maintaining competitive on the SYSU-MM01 and RegDB.

title: A Generative Strategy for Target-Oriented Molecular Design: Integrating Docking Scores with Drug-Likeness Constraints
authors: Zhicheng Yang, Xiaolong Zhang, Xiaoli Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: With the growing application of deep learning in drug design, efficiently generating molecules with desirable drug-like properties and target specificity remains a key challenge. Existing methods often rely on complex fusion of molecular and protein features, leading to high data demands and training costs. To address this, a novel molecule generation model based on multi-constraint optimization is proposed, incorporating docking scores, Lipinski’s Rule of Five, and other pharmacological constraints to guide generation. The model is built on a Bidirectional Gated Recurrent Unit (BiGRU) and improves training efficiency through cross-entropy loss optimization. Experimental results show that the proposed approach achieves superior performance in molecular validity, novelty, and uniqueness, and generates compounds with lower binding energies to target proteins, significantly enhancing the practicality and scalability of molecular design.

title: Collaborative Design of Antenna Array Topology and AP Deployment for Distributed MIMO Systems
authors: Lihua Pang, Haobing Jin, Yang Zhang, Zenghong Ke, Ao Du, Yijian Chen, Anyi Wang
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: Distributed multiple-input multiple-output (D-MIMO) systems have great potential in improving spectrum efficiency, service quality, and network capacity. A key factor affecting their performance is the design of access points (APs) placement and subarray configuration. This paper aims to maximize the ergodic sum rate by collaboratively optimizing the arrangement of subarray layout and the positioning of APs. Specifically, by employing uniform planar antenna arrays (UPAs) in the AP's subarray setup and strategically placing APs within a predefined zone, we can characterize the ergodic sum rate effectively. Given the complexity of the ergodic sum rate's expression, the optimization process begins by deriving an approximate expression through Jensen's inequality. This approximation then guides a reformulated optimization problem. Under fixed AP positions, the subarray antenna topology is initially optimized, followed by refining the locations of the APs. An iterative algorithm is employed to finalize the optimal antenna array designs and the precise deployment sites for multiple APs. Numerical simulation results show that the proposed approach achieves a near-optimal performance. For scenarios where several APs are circularly arranged to serve evenly distributed users, our findings suggest that the optimal deployment radius should be 0.63 times the cell radius when using UPAs with a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.91 \lambda$</tex> spacing.

title: Phase- jitter -tolerant characterization of programmable photonic circuits
authors: Jiajia Wang, Haoran Zhang, Shuying Li, Shuran Zhang, Yunping Bai, Xingyuan Xu
abstract: We demonstrated a universal and phase-jitter-tolerant characterization technique to measure the dynamic performance of programmable photonic integrated circuits (PICs). This approach provides a promising solution for PIC characterization, enabling accelerated physical parameter training.

title: A $\beta$-VAE-WGAN-Based Traffic Augmentation Model for Enhanced IoT Intrusion Detection
authors: Tong Liu, Yu Wu, Li Zhou, Mengting He, Gao Chen, Xuanrui Xiong
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Wireless Communications and Signal Processing (WCSP)
abstract: With the rapid growth of Internet of Things (IoT) devices, network security challenges-especially in malicious traffic detection-have become more prominent. Traditional Network Intrusion Detection Systems (NIDS) face significant challenges due to the high heterogeneity and dimensional complexity of IoT data. To improve NIDS performance in IoT environments, this paper proposes VWGM (Variational AutoencoderWasserstein Generative Adversarial Network-Based Generative Model with Multi-scale Feature Fusion and Coordinate Attention Mechanism). The model integrates a multi-scale feature fusion mechanism, a Beta Coordinate Attention Module (BCA), and introduces a Multi-Scale Soft Pooling Module (MSSPM) to improve data generation quality and feature extraction. VWGM maintains high structural consistency and semantic fidelity when generating IoT network traffic, effectively addressing the data scarcity problem. Experimental results on the MedBIoT dataset demonstrate that VWGM outperforms existing generative models in both Ablation Study Analysis and the generation of key feature data. In intrusion detection tasks, the model achieves significantly higher accuracy than CTGAN and SyNIG. This further validates that the proposed model has significant advantages in detection accuracy and overall performance in IoT security scenarios.

title:
Spatiotemporal Trend Fusion Feature Graph Convolution Network for Spatial Interpolation in Traffic Scenes
                    <sup>⋆</sup>
authors: Zhiang Hou, Shiyong Lan, Xinyuan Zhou, Wujiang Zhu, Yao Ren
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: Sensors are always sparsely distributed in traffic networks due to high deployment costs, sensor damage, etc. Insufficient data may affect our perception of traffic scenarios, resulting in the inability of intelligent transportation systems (ITS) to efficiently perform traffic monitoring and scenario decisions. Spatial interpolation methods are used to infer the status of locations where no sensors are deployed. However, existing methods still have the following limitations: (1) Mainly interpolated unobserved nodes by extracting spatiotemporal dependencies between nodes, but ignored complex interaction patterns in feature dimensions. (2) Recent methods generally used standard TCN to extract temporal correlations, which is affected by abnormal data. (3) When extracting spatial correlations, the use of deep GCN layer can lead to over-smoothing problem. To mitigate these limitations, we propose a novel spatial interpolation model, namely, Spatiotemporal Trend Fusion Feature Graph Convolution Network (STFGCN). Specifically, a novel feature graph convolution network is used to capture complex interaction patterns. Secondly, the trend capture branch is used to alleviate the impact of abnormal data on TCN. Finally, a dual-stage spatial module is used to solve the degradation of detailed feature representations in deep GCN layer. Experimental results on six real traffic datasets demonstrate that our method outperforms state-of-the-art baseline models.

title: Feature-Aligned Diffusion: A Framework for High-Fidelity fMRI-to-Image Reconstruction
authors: LIU FUWEI
publish: 2025 22nd International Computer Conference on Wavelet Active Media Technology and Information Processing (ICCWAMTIP)
abstract: Recent fMRI-to-image reconstruction methods have primarily focused on associating fMRI signals with specific conditioning inputs of pre-trained diffusion models. However, such conditioning introduces information loss with respect to the original visual content, as the generative process of diffusion models tends to obscure this deficiency, resulting in generation based on reconstruction, rather than true reconstruction of the perceived stimuli. To address this issue, this paper proposes a feature-aligned reconstruction framework, which guides the diffusion trajectory through visual feature alignment extracted from fMRI signals, thereby overcoming the limitations of fixed conditional control in existing diffusion-based approaches. Experimental results on the Natural Scenes Dataset demonstrate that the proposed method achieves higher fidelity and semantic consistency in reconstructed images, providing a more faithful mapping between brain activity and visual perception.

title: Asymmetric U-Net with Gaussian Splatting for Single-View 3D Reconstruction
authors: Yifan Wang, Zhirui Xu, Xianting Zeng, Wenjun Zhou, Bo Peng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: With the rapid advancement of computer vision and graphics, high-quality single-view 3D reconstruction has become increasingly significant in applications such as autonomous driving, robotics, and virtual reality. Traditional methods often struggle with the inherent ill-posed nature of single-view reconstruction, leading to limited accuracy and reduced detail retention. To address these challenges, we introduce an innovative framework that integrates an asymmetric U-Net architecture with 3D Gaussian splatting for single-view 3D reconstruction. Furthermore, our approach incorporates a novel 3D smoothing filter that constrains the maximum frequency of the 3D representation, effectively mitigating high-frequency artifacts in out-of-distribution rendering. By synergistically combining implicit and explicit representations, our method leverages the strengths of both to enhance reconstruction efficiency and quality. Experiments conducted on the SRN-Cars dataset demonstrate that our framework outperforms existing methods in quantitative metrics and qualitative assessments, achieving higher reconstruction accuracy and smoother surfaces.

title: Comprehensive Research on Trust-Based Clustering and Routing for Secure Network Communication
authors: Talari Ashok, Sabout Nagaraju
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: In recent years, trust-based clustering and routing has emerged as an effective approach for enhancing security and energy efficiency in the context of Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs), Mobile Ad Hoc Networks (MANETs) and Internet of Things (IoT). By combining trust evaluation with clustering and routing mechanisms, these methods ensure secure data delivery by isolating malicious nodes. The optimization algorithms such as Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), Genetic Algorithm (GA), Bacteria Foraging Optimization (BFO) and Crow Search (CS) effectively enabled intelligent cluster head selection and energy-aware routing, whereas Machine Learning (ML) and Deep Learning (DL) techniques introduced predictive trust modelling and adaptive decision making. With rising adoption of Low Power Wide Area Network (LPWAN) technologies like LoRaWAN, combination of trust-based optimization becomes required for ensuring secure, long-range and energy-constrained communications in IoT deployments. Despite these advancements, existing models face challenges like high computational overhead, difficulty in handling dynamic topologies, limited scalability and vulnerability to sophisticated attacks. This survey presents survey of recent optimization-driven and learning-assisted trust-based clustering and routing approaches by highlighting their methodologies, performance benefits and limitations for large-scale real-time deployments.

title: Design of Dual-Axis Servo Laser Ranging Pan - Tilt Scanning System
authors: Yulei Cui, Xingxing Shi, Yu Huang, Hao Zhang, Yiran Hu, Guang Wang
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotics, Control and Automation Engineering (RCAE)
abstract: Aiming at the problem that the surface shape accuracy of heliostats, a key component of tower-type solar thermal power plants, affects the solar energy concentration efficiency, this paper designs a heliostat surface shape accuracy scanning system based on a dual-axis servo laser ranging pan-tilt. The system is composed of a controller, a dual-axis servo pan-tilt, and a high-precision laser range-finder. Firstly, a position loop controller for the dualaxis servo pan-tilt is constructed based on the Linear Active Disturbance Rejection Control (LADRC) algorithm to improve the position positioning accuracy and scanning cycle. Then, the pan-tilt carries a high-precision laser range-finder to perform a holographic 3D scan on the back of the heliostat to obtain 3D point cloud data. Finally, the root mean square error of the point cloud is used as the standard for evaluating the surface shape quality. Through practical applications in industrial sites, the results show that the system is stable and reliable, and easy to deploy, meeting the requirements of automation and intelligence for surface shape accuracy detection during heliostat production.

title: Construction of Multi-Scale Biostatistical Analysis Framework and its Application in Biomedical Signal Feature Recognition and Classification
authors: Pengwei Zhu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Mobile Networks and Wireless Communications (ICMNWC)
abstract: Electrocardiogram and electroencephalogram (EEG) signals, as important carriers reflecting physiological activities, present significant challenges in terms of complexity, non-stationary characteristics, and susceptibility to interference. Any conventional processing strategy often struggles to maintain stable performance under unfavorable signal conditions. Therefore, this study constructs a multi-scale analysis approach that integrates fractal analysis, higher-order statistical features, and harmonic average box dimensions. It is used to enhance the expressive ability of the signal structure at different levels and improve the reliable feature quality of the classification model. The research process uses a decision tree model for signal category identification after feature generation. The experiment section deals with various wireless modulated signals as well as real electrocardiogram information. The samples of the electrocardiogram are held as a part of the assessment to test the strength of the approach on various kinds of data. The general findings indicate that this framework continues to have a clear quality discrimination capability within a low signal to noise ratio environment. The modulated signal has given high recognition rate under some conditions and obtained full accuracy classification performance under some conditions. The modified fractal dimension features of fractal intercept correlation fail to provide good effects in recognition in the electrocardiogram signal analysis, whereas the standard fractal dimension features do. The paper noted that its discriminatory nature in regard to abnormal waveforms is stronger. The overall research demonstrates potential of an obvious application, namely, in such the case as real-time biological signal processing and health monitoring. The next line of study will be to increase the use of the model over large scale datasets and research its how to couple with deep learning models, to facilitate further use of this analytical framework in clinical practice.

title: Augmented Reality-Enhanced Robot Teleoperation for Collecting User Demonstrations
authors: Shiqi Gong, Sebastián Zudaire, Chi Zhang, Zhen Li
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotics, Control and Automation Engineering (RCAE)
abstract: Traditional industrial robot programming is often complex and time-consuming, typically requiring weeks or even months of effort from expert programmers. Although Programming by Demonstration (PbD) offers a more accessible alternative, intuitive interfaces for robot control and demonstration collection remain challenging. To address this, we propose an Augmented Reality (AR)-enhanced robot teleoperation system that integrates AR-based control with spatial point cloud rendering, enabling intuitive, contact-free demonstrations. This approach allows operators to control robots remotely without entering the workspace or using conventional tools like the teach pendant. The proposed system is generally applicable and has been demonstrated on ABB robot platforms, specifically validated with the IRB 1200 industrial robot and the GoFa 5 collaborative robot. A user study evaluates the impact of real-time environmental perception, specifically with and without point cloud rendering, on task completion accuracy, efficiency, and user confidence. Results indicate that enhanced perception significantly improves task performance by 28% and enhances user experience, as reflected by a 12% increase in the System Usability Scale (SUS) score. This work contributes to the advancement of intuitive robot teleoperation, AR interface design, environmental perception, and teleoperation safety mechanisms in industrial settings for demonstration collection. The collected demonstrations may serve as valuable training data for machine learning applications.

title: Auction Consensus Algorithm with Loss Mechanism for Decentralized Task Allocation
authors: Jose Rodriguez, Wenjie Dong, Constantine Tarawneh, Qi Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Multi-Robot and Multi-Agent Systems (MRS)
abstract: This paper presents an Auction-Consensus Algorithm with a Loss Mechanism (ACALM), a decentralized task allocation method for multi-robot systems that enhances the existing Consensus-Based Auction Algorithm (CBAA) by incorporating a novel loss propagation mechanism. In contrast to purely greedy bidding strategies, it enables agents to dynamically update task priorities based on the accumulated loss from previously unsuccessful bids. This extended work reduces globally inefficient allocations caused by early suboptimal decisions. The proposed approach is evaluated through large-scale simulations in thousands of randomized scenarios and swarm sizes ranging from 5 to 120 robots. Compared to existing CBAA and GCAA algorithms, ACALM yields task assignments with higher global efficiency on average. The results also show that ACALM maintains effectiveness with larger swarms, suggesting strong robustness in large decentralized contexts. However, this improvement comes with an increase in communication overhead due to additional consensus rounds. Potential extensions include methods to reduce communication costs, support for multiple assignments per robot, and verification of functionality under asynchronous communication.

title: Velocity-Constrained Collaborative Control for Multi-UAVs: An Autonomous Inspection in Power Distribution Networks Case
authors: Limei Zhou, Linjian Cheng, Liang Sun, Pengfei Jiang, Xin Lu, Guanying Wang
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Robotics, Control and Automation Engineering (RCAE)
abstract: This article presents a velocity-constrained collaborative control strategy for multiple unmanned aerial vehicles (multi-UAVs) in autonomous inspection tasks within power distribution networks. By constructing a log-type barrier Lyapunov function (BLF) into the optimized backstepping strategy, the approach enforces strict velocity constraints to ensure safe and efficient operation. An identifier-actor-critic reinforcement learning (IAC-RL) framework is incorporated to adaptively estimate unknown dynamics and optimize leader-follower formation control (LFC) in real-time. Stability analysis demonstrates that tracking errors are semi-globally uniformly ultimately bounded (SUGGB), with velocity constraints preserved. Simulation results confirm the scheme's efficacy in achieving stable formations along overhead power lines.

title: VulSCS: A Source Code Vulnerability Detection System Using Secondary Code Slicing
authors: Yong Zhong, Bin Liu, Wenyin Yang, Junxian Ye, Jihui Liand Fen Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics (SMC)
abstract: In the context of the information age, the frequent occurrence of software vulnerabilities has emerged as a critical issue demanding immediate resolution. Traditional vulnerability detection methods have struggled to keep pace with the escalating security demands, while the advent of deep learning technology has introduced novel solutions to software vulnerability detection. Deep learning not only facilitates the automatic extraction of features, thereby reducing the cost of manual intervention, but also demonstrates remarkable advantages across various domains. In recent years, research on vulnerability detection based on deep learning has achieved notable progress, yet it still faces several limitations. This study focuses on C/C++ program vulnerability detection and proposes an enhanced approach, VulSCS, based on secondary slicing. By performing secondary slicing on source code exhibiting vulnerable behaviors, this method extracts code segments with higher representational value, thereby capturing richer vulnerability-related features. Experimental results indicate that, compared to state-of-the-art vulnerability detection tools, VulSCS improves detection accuracy by 3.2% and enhances detection efficiency by approximately threefold. This research offers new perspectives and methodologies for deep learningbased software vulnerability detection.

title: Heuristics Evaluation of Moodle E-Learning Using Specialized Educational Usability Indicators
authors: Ranty Deviana Siahaan, Sri Suning Kusumawardani, Indriana Hidayah
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Information Technology, Information Systems and Electrical Engineering (ICITISEE)
abstract: The rapid transition to online learning during and after the COVID-19 pandemic has urged educational institutions to re-examine the usability and pedagogical effectiveness of their Learning Management Systems (LMS). However, most existing evaluations rely on generic usability frameworks that overlook learning-specific aspects such as instructional design and learner motivation. This study proposes and applies 23 specialized heuristics indicators tailored for e-Learning usability assessment to evaluate the Moodle-based LMS of SMA Unggul Del (SUD), Indonesia. The indicators were synthesized from prior research and refined to capture four core dimensions: general usability, instructional design, course workspace usability, and motivational learning. An expert-based heuristics evaluation involving nine evaluators, comprising lecturers, graduate students, and UX professionals was conducted using structured task scenarios for both student and teacher interfaces. The findings revealed 126 usability issues (76 student-related, 50 teacher-related) distributed across 23 indicators, alongside quantitative ratings of indicators importance. Results show that 22 of the 23 indicators were deemed essential, validating their relevance for holistic e-Learning evaluation. Furthermore, the study provides a detailed list of usability issues and improvement recommendations to guide LMS developers in enhancing user experience and pedagogical quality. This research advances existing heuristics methods by embedding educational heuristics into usability evaluation, bridging the gap between human-computer interactions and learning design, and offering a practical framework for continuous LMS enhancement.
